Description: Hematite cylinder seal; the king with a mace faces the suppliant goddess; between them, one above the other, are a couchant bull (?) looking back over its shoulder at the king, a hedgehog at right angles to the remainder of the design, and a striding, kilted figure on a base-line, who faces the goddess and raises one hand. To the left of the inscription two crude figures were cut, one above the other, to mask the remains of the earlier inscription: one is kilted, facing right beside a disc (chipped) and crescent, and the other is a "bow-legged dwarf", besides whom is a monkey (?); the two-line inscription is in a crooked frame and is incised over the erasure of an earlier inscription; chipped; the side with the inscription has been considerably rubbed down.
Bibliographic references: Collon 1986a / Catalogue of the Western Asiatic Seals in the British Museum: Cylinder Seals III: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian Periods (259)
Leichty E et al 1988a / Catalogue of the Babylonian Tablets in the British Museum, volume VIII: Tablets from Sippar 3 (p.167)
Condition: Fair; chipped; side with the inscription has been considerably rubbed down.
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
Acquisition notes: Acquired by the British Museum as a result of Budge's second mission to Egypt and Mesopotamia in 1887-1888; the mission was intended to investigate the "leakage" of tablets from sites supposedly guarded on behalf of the British Museum. Further notes on acquisition and bibliographic references relating to acquisition in Leichty catalogue introduction pp.xv-xvii.
